awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: A Lightweight, Low-Cost, Liquid-Metal Cooling Vest for Prolonged Cooling
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a personal cooling system for high-heat work environments such as shipyards, foundries, boiler workshops, and mining and construction sites where workers are exposed to heat exhaustion. Additional potential markets exist in medical, sports, emergency response, military, and animal care fields. The product will compete in the global personal cooling garment market. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a conduction-based, cooling cycle technology using highly thermally conductive fluidic metal, gallium alloy. Gallium alloy is liquid at room temperature and is commonly known as liquid metal (LM). Due to its fluidic nature, LM can be pumped into a microfluidic channel using a low-power pump. Also, LM is 28 times more conductive (16.5W/m·K) than water, which helps absorb heat in a second by conduction, unlike the convection-based cooling cycle.  Conventional refrigeration cooling cycles require a high power-consuming compressor to reduce heat transfer time. Low power conduction-based heat transfer along with microfluidic LM flows allow the LM to be used as the primary coolant in the novel personal cooling system. The outcome is a lightweight, low-power, low-cost, LM wearable personal cooling system that can provide day-long high cooling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Major Activities: steadfast in our mission to align our high-performance personal cooling system with its intended market. We focused on several key objectives:

The team has developed a high-level comprehensive commercial plan and submitted an SBIR Phase I application to the National Institute of Health. The team has engaged with various companies in the solar thermal industries as part of this project and raised $50,000 post-cohort equity investment for prototype development.

For our invention, we've pinpointed the beachhead market to be iron and steel mills and foundries. Our analyses have categorized potential markets into two primary business models. First, the regulatory compliance-driven model targets sectors such as iron and steel mills, electrical utility line workers, and first responders, including firefighters. This model emphasizes adherence to industry standards and safety regulations. On the other hand, the demand-driven model, also referred to as the benefits/carrot model, focuses on sectors where the inherent benefits of our invention drive its adoption. This includes surgical theater and operating room medical professionals, those involved in leisure activities like sports and auto racing, and medical users, particularly patients with multiple sclerosis. Both models showcase the versatile applications and potential demand for our innovative solution.

Participation in various trade shows and conferences provided significant exposure to market trends and opportunities, greatly enhancing our strategic planning and market positioning. As part of our NSF I-Corps project, we attended several key events to gather insights and feedback directly from potential customers and stakeholders. One of the major events was the International Congress on Safety and Health at Work in Sydney, Australia, where we engaged with industry professionals and safety experts to understand the specific needs and challenges faced by workers in high-heat environments. This congress was instrumental in refining our value proposition for the lightweight low-cost liquid-metal cooling vest, ensuring it met the rigorous safety standards and expectations of the market. Additionally, we participated in trade shows in Saudi Arabia, which provided a unique perspective on the Middle Eastern market. Here, we connected with key industry leaders and stakeholders, gaining insights into the region's specific requirements for personal cooling systems. Our visit to the oil fields in Egypt further enriched our understanding of the practical applications and challenges associated with using our technology in extreme heat conditions. These engagements allowed us to conduct over 130 in-depth customer interviews, integrating valuable insights into our product development process. Through these international engagements, we gathered critical feedback that helped identify unique market requirements and refine our technology accordingly. These experiences not only broadened our understanding of global market demands but also established crucial connections and collaborations essential for successful commercialization. By integrating insights from diverse environments, we ensured that our product aligns with the highest standards of performance and reliability, making it a compelling solution for various high-heat work environments globally.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 08/05/2024
Modified by: Fernando Gómez-Baquero
